name: emcare
title: Extended Codes CodeSystem
description: Set of codes identified as being needed but not found in existing Code Systems

concept.definition: Unique identifier provided or a universal ID, if used in the country

concept.display: Blood in the stool in this Illness
concept.definition: The client is reported to have or has had blood in the stool in this Illness
Use documented weight to see if there is weight loss, if no recent documentation of weight, ask mother if the child has lost weight
Ask the mother if there has been a recent change in the child's appearance or changing of eyes which have become more sunken (more retracted) since the diarrhoea started.

concept.display: Two or more episodes of diarrhea in the past 2 months
concept.definition: The child is reported to have had two or more episodes of diarrhea in the past 2 months
The child has "Fever Reported" (history of fever) if the child has had any fever with this illness

Length of time the child has had fever
- 7 days or less (1 week or less)
- 8 to 30 days
-More than 30 days"

concept.display: Has Fever been present every day for more than 7 days
concept.definition:
If the fever has been present for more than 7 days, ask if the fever has been present every day. A fever that has been present every day for more than 7 days can mean that the
child has a more severe disease such as typhoid fever. The child will need referral for further assessment.
The child is reported to have, or appears to be in pain. It is important to assess for pain which could be a sign of a source of infection when the child has reported or measured fever.

To determine if a child has an ear problem, you should ask, look, and feel.Ear Problems are common. Though ear infections rarely cause death, they are the main cause of deafness and can cause learning problems at school. It is very important to assess, classify, and treat ear problems to prevent pain in the short term, and more serious consequences in the long-term. "
Ear Pain can mean that the child has an ear infection. If the caregiver is not sure that the child has ear pain, ask if the child has been irritable and rubbing his ear.
The child is reported or appears to have pus discharging from the ear. Use words the caregiver understands.

How long the child has had the discharge from the ear. 
- Less than 14 days (Less than 2 weeks)
- More than 14 days (2 weeks or more)
The child is reported to have or appears to have an eye problem
The child is reported to have or appears to have a skin problem
The child is reported to have or appears to have itchy skin
The child is known to have sickle disease

concept.display: Pus Seen Draining from the Ear
concept.definition: The client has pus draining from the ear which has been seen by the health care worker

concept.display: Pus Seen Draining from the Ear for how long?
concept.definition: The length of time the client has or has had pus draining from the ear
The client has a Stiff neck

The child is unable to use a limb (arm or leg) on examination. It is important to assess for refusal to use a limb which could be a sign of a bone or joint infection when the child has reported or measured fever.

concept.display: Warm Tender or Swollen Joint or Bone
concept.definition: The child has a warm tender or swollen joint or bone which could be a sign of a infection when the child has reported or measured fever.
The client has a Runny nose

concept.display: Large lymph nodes on two or more sites
concept.definition: The child has large lymph nodes on two or more sites. Examine the neck, armpits and groin to see if you can identify large lymph nodes in 2 or more regions.

concept.display: Rapidly spreading, extensive, or not responding to oral antibiotics
concept.definition: The child has cellulitis which is rapidly spreading, extensive, or not responding to oral antibiotics
The client has Scalp Infection (tinea capitis)
The client has severe chickenpox rash
The client has disseminated herpes zoster
The client has Herpes Zoster with Eye Involvement

Signs of severe impetigo / folliculitis include:
- Skin Lesions 4 cm or larger
- Red Skin Streaks
- Tender Nodes (Nodules) under the skin
- Skin infection extends to muscle
- No signs of severe Impetigo / Folliculitis
The client has Extensive impetigo lesions requiring oral antibiotics
The client has Extensive molluscum lesions

concept.definition: The client has severe acute moist or weeping eczema

concept.display: Add a Skin or Mouth or Eye Problem
concept.definition: The health care worker would like to add a Skin or Mouth or Eye problem found during the physical exam
The client has palmar pallor

"Oedema of both feet means severe acute malnutrition.
LOOK and FEEL to determine if the child has oedema of both feet. Using your thumbs, press the topside of both feet simultaneously for 3 seconds on the top side of each foot. The child has oedema if a dent remains in the child’s foot when you lift your thumb.
Oedema is when an unusually large amount of fluid gathers in the child’s tissues. The tissues become filled with the fluid and look swollen or puffed up. If a child has oedema of both feet they should be referred to inpatient care."
The child has open skin lesions
The child has visible and severe weight loss
The child has swelling around cheek/jaw
The duration of mumps observed

concept.display: Prefer to take Rectal Temperature (second measurement)
concept.definition: The health care worker prefers to take the child's rectal temperature

The child's rectal temperature (temperature taken in the rectum), measured in degrees Celcius. Only consider taking rectal temperature if trained.
A second temperature measurement is required to confirm fever or low body temperature in a young infant, if it is the only severe sign (of possible Severe Bacterial Infection), 30 minutes (after the first measurement and after removing cloting to let the baby who has fever cool, or wrapping the baby who has low body temperature)

Temperature ranges for young infants under 2 months:
- Under 36.0 : hypothermia (low body temperature)
- 36.0 to 38.5 : normal 
- 38.5 and above : fever
The client's second temperature measurement is not feasible

Autocalculated temperature range based on axillary temperature in degrees Celcius (add 0.5 for rectal temperature)
 
Temperature ranges for young infants under 2 months:
- Under 35.5: low body temperature (hypothermia)
- 35.5 to 37.9: normal
- 38.0 and above: fever

If the infant has fever, remove a layer of clothing and let the baby cool. If the body temperature is low, wrap the baby in additional clothing to warm her.
Obvious cause of fever

High malaria risk: in area where more than 5% of fever cases in children 2 to 59 months are attributable to malaria
Low malaria risk: in area where fewer than 5% of fever cases in children 2 to 59 months are attributable to malaria, but where the risk is not negligible.
No malaria risk: malaria transmission does not normally occur in the area, and imported malaria is uncommon.

concept.display: Does not appear to be Underweight

concept.display: Pain or Difficulty Passing Urine or Crying when Passing Urine
concept.definition: The child is reported to have or appears to have pain or difficulty passing urine (in younger children this may appear as crying when passing urine)
The child is reported to have or appears to have painful skin or a skin problem
The child is reported to have or appears to have ear pain
The child is reported to have or appears to have pain which does not fit into the other categories
The client has a generalised skin problem
The client has a localised skin problem
The client does not have a generalised or localised skin problem
The child has an abscess - Hot tender swelling
The child has an abscess that is deep or extends to muscle
The child has cellulitis - warm / hot tender skin - appears red in paler skin tones and dark red, dark brown, grey or purple in darker skin tones

concept.display: Papular Itching Rash (Prurigo) - Itching rash with small papules and scratch marks. Dark spots with pale centre
concept.definition:
The client has Papular Urticaria or Papular Pruritic Eruptions 
• Itchy papules at different stages of evolution.
• Found on the arms and legs.
• Healed lesions are often dark/ hyperpigmented.
• The itch is difficult to manage.
• Essential to exclude scabies.

concept.display: Ringworm (Tinea) - An itchy circular lesion with a raised edge and fine scaly area in the centre with loss of hair.  May also be found on body or web on feet
concept.definition:
The client has Ringworm (Tinea) - 
• An itchy circular lesion with a raised edge and fine scaly area.
• Scalp lesions may result in loss of hair

concept.display: Scabies - Rash and excoriations on torso; burrows in web space and wrists, face spared
concept.definition:
The client has Scabies -
• Intense itching, more severe at night.
• Small burrows between fingers, tows, elbow areas and buttocks.
• Secondary infection may occur.
• Small babies may have vesicles and pustules on the palms and soles and face.
• The infestation spreads easily, usually affecting more than one person in the household

concept.display: Chickenpox - Vesicles over body.  Vesicles appear progressively over days and form scabs after they rupture
concept.definition:
The client has Chickenpox - Mild fever preceding the rash.
• Rash begins on the trunk and face,
later spreads to the arms and legs.
• Vesicles appear progressively over days and forms scabs
after they rupture.
• Contagious from the fever starts until all lesions have
crusted.
• Usually lasts for about 1 week.

concept.display:
Herpes Zoster -  Vesicles in one area on one side of body with intense pain or scars plus shooting pain.  
Uncommon in children except where they are immuno-compromised (e.g. if infected with HIV)
concept.definition:
The client has Herpes Zoster -  Vesicles in one area on one side of body with intense pain or scars plus shooting pain.
• They are uncommon in children except when they are immune-compromised

concept.display: Impetigo or Folliculitis - Red, Tender, Warm Crusts or Small lesions
concept.definition:
The client has Impetigo- Pustules and papules with honey -coloured crusts.
• Commonly starts on the face or buttocks, then spreads to the neck, hands, arms and legs.

concept.display: Molluscum Contagiosum - Skin coloured pearly white papules with central umbilication. Most commonly seen on face and trunk in children.
concept.definition:
The client has Molluscum Contagiosum -Caused by a poxvirus.
• Dome-shaped papules with a central depression
(umblication).
• Most commonly seen on the face and trunk in children

concept.display: Warts - Papules or nodules with a rough (Verrucous) surface
concept.definition:
The client has Warts - Appears as papules or nodules with a rough surface.
• Seen most often on the hands and fingers, but can be
found anywhere on
the body.

concept.display: Seborrhoea - Greasy scales and redness on central face and body folds
concept.definition:
The client has Seborrhoeic Dermatitis - Greasy scales and redness on central face, body folds.
• The scalp, face, ears and skin folds (e.g. axillae, groins, under the breasts) are commonly affected.

concept.display: Fixed Drug Reactions - Generalised red, wide spread with small bumps or blisters; or one or more dark skin areas
concept.definition:
The client has Fixed Drug Reaction - One or more dark round or oval skin lesions with central vesicles .
• The lesions recur on the same spot, and increase in number with each successive attack

concept.display: Eczema - Wet oozing sores or excoriated, thick patches
concept.definition:
The client has Eczema - Erythematous (red), sometimes scaly plaques found on the face, flexures, trunk and extensors.
• Yellow pustules which crust indicate
secondary bacterial infection.

The client has Steven Johnson Syndrome (SJS) - Severe and acute reaction due to many drugs, the commonest being cotrimoxazole or nevirapine.
• Lesions involve the skin as well as the mucous membranes (e.g. eyes, mouth and genitalia).
• May start as widespread red irregular rash with or without blisters. The blisters rupture leaving denuded areas of skin.
• May cause difficulty in breathing.
The impetigo skin lesions cover an area of 4 cm or larger
The impetigo is associated with red skin streaks
The impetigo is associated with tender Nodes (Nodules) under the skin
The skin Infection extends to muscle

concept.display: No signs of severe Impetigo / Folliculitis
concept.definition: The child does not have any signs of severe Impetigo / Folliculitis
The health care worker would like to add a skin problem
The health care worker would like to add an Oral Sores or Mouth Ulcers problem
The health care worker would like to add an Eye problem

concept.definition: The healthcare worker would not like to add a Skin or Mouth or Eye Problem
The caregiver does not give the client any breastmilk at all

The care giver is giving appropriate  replacement milk
